title: Ruby, Rails ebooks [birdwin]
description:
Here are 17 electronic books on Ruby and/or Rails. The naming scheme is as follows:

[Amazon Average Customer Rating]-[Number of Reviews].[Number of Pages].[Month of Publication]-[Year of Publication].[Publisher].[Title].[Extension]

Here are the contents:

3.5-28.182.8-2006.OReilly.Ruby.on.Rails.Up.and.Running.chm
4-5.267.5-2008.Pragmatic.Programmers.Deploying.Rails.Applications.A.Step-by-Step.Guide.pdf
4-6.433.1-2009.OReilly.Head.First.Rails.pdf
4-28.910.11-2007.Addison.Wesley.The.Rails.Way.pdf
4.5-9.359.1-2008.OReilly.Advanced.Rails.pdf
4.5-11.309.6-2007.No.Starch.Press.Ruby.by.Example.Concepts.and.Code.pdf
4.5-14.297.6-2006.Pragmatic.Programmers.Rails.Recipes.pdf
4.5-14.600.1-2007.OReilly.Rails.Cookbook.chm
4.5-20.500.5-2008.Sitepoint.Simply.Rails.2.pdf
4.5-21.888.11-2006.Addison.Wesley.The.Ruby.Way.2nd.Edition.chm
4.5-24.564.7-2007.Addison.Wesley.RailsSpace.Building.a.Social.Networking.Website.with.Ruby.on.Rails.pdf
4.5-29.908.7-2006.OReilly.Ruby.Cookbook.pdf
4.5-108.715.12-2006.Pragmatic.Programmers.Agile.Web.Development.With.Rails.2nd.Edition.pdf
5-2.448.11-2008.OReilly.Learning.Rails.pdf
5-6.407.5-2008.Pragmatic.Programmers.Advanced.Rails.Recipes.pdf
5-22.446.1-2008.OReilly.The.Ruby.Programming.Language.pdf
5-29.664.3-2007.Apress.Beginning.Ruby.From.Novice.to.Professional.pdf

I removed spaces from the filenames so moving in a shell would be easier. 14 are PDF files, and 3 are CHMs. For Linux readers, chmsee is the best CHM viewer I've seen. I'm not sure about Macs.

I've got ebook packs for lots of other things [from artificial intelligence to LaTeX to reverse engineering, and everything in between] coming soon.

Feedback, especially on the naming scheme, is much appreciated. This is the pattern I use to name ebooks on my machine, and I'm especially curious to hear what others think. While I don't think that the Amazon avg. customer rating is a foolproof indicator of a book's quality (look at SICP, for example), it's the best I've found, in addition to skimming the table of contents. And if anyone knows how to make Nautilus sort a 4.5* filename AFTER a 4* filename (aside from reversing the overall sort order, smartasses), please let me know.

Enjoy!
